individual_results.base_prompt:
Write an SCP report about a researcher who begins finding handwritten notes from their future self, warning about a containment breach that hasn't happened yet. The notes become increasingly desperate and incoherent, sometimes containing information that contradicts known reality. Include the Foundation's attempts to determine if this is an actual temporal anomaly or psychological manipulation by a contained entity, and the researcher's struggle to trust their own perception.

First person (researcher's perspective with interspersed notes), past tense.

<SEED> Length: 1000 words.
individual_results.model_response:
**Item #:** SCP-XXXX  
**Object Class:** Euclid  
**Special Containment Procedures:** Researcher Elena Voss (Site-19, Personnel File: R-0789) is to be placed under Observation Protocol Theta-9. All personal belongings, including writing implements and notebooks, are to be inspected daily. Any anomalous documents discovered are to be secured and analyzed by the Temporal Anomalies Division (TAD) and the Psychological Integrity Unit (PIU). Researcher Voss is to be restricted from accessing SCP-XXXX-1 (The Archive) and any classified data related to temporal phenomena. She is to be monitored via passive surveillance in her quarters and during work hours. Weekly psychological evaluations are mandatory.

**Description:** SCP-XXXX is a phenomenon involving Researcher Elena Voss, who began receiving handwritten notes from an unknown source claiming to be her future self. The notes are written on standard Foundation memo paper (Type-7, issued to all personnel), in Voss’s handwriting, and contain warnings about a containment breach at Site-19 that has not yet occurred. The first note appeared on 2023-04-12, tucked inside her locked desk drawer, which she had not opened in three days.

---

**Log Entry: 2023-04-12**  
I found it this morning. A single sheet of memo paper, folded neatly, tucked between the false bottom of my desk drawer. I didn’t put it there. I’ve kept that drawer locked since last week. The handwriting… it’s mine. But it’s not *me*. The phrasing is too urgent, too panicked. Like someone writing in a hurry, but also… like they were trying to be precise.  

> *Don’t trust the lights. They’ll go out at 03:17. When they do, don’t look at the corridor. They’re not supposed to be there. They’re not supposed to be alive.*  
>  
> *You’re already too late. They’re coming through the walls.*  

I laughed at first. Then I checked the time. 03:16. The lights flickered. Just once. I stood up, heart pounding. Nothing happened. No one came. I told myself it was stress. I’ve been working on Project Echo for weeks. But I couldn’t shake the feeling that I’d just read a prophecy.

---

**Log Entry: 2023-04-14**  
More notes. Three of them. All in the same place—my desk, my locked drawer. I’ve triple-checked the lock. It’s not being picked. I’ve seen no one enter my quarters.  

> *The blue room is not blue. It’s red. You know this. You’ve seen it. They’re using the old elevator shaft. They’re not ghosts. They’re not SCPs. They’re the ones who were supposed to be erased.*  
>  
> *Don’t let Dr. Kael see the files. He’s not who he says he is. He’s not human.*  

I showed the notes to Dr. Kael. He looked at me like I’d lost my mind. “Elena, you’re exhausted. You’ve been working 18-hour days. We’re all tired.” But he didn’t ask to see the notes. He just told me to rest.  

I looked at the files. The ones he’s been reviewing. The ones from 2018. The ones marked “Classified – Do Not Access.” I didn’t open them. But I *remembered* them. I’ve never seen them before.  

---

**Log Entry: 2023-04-17**  
I found a note in my coat pocket. I hadn’t worn it in days. It was cold outside. I didn’t go out.  

> *They’re in the vents. They’ve been in the vents since the fire. The fire that never happened. You were there. You were supposed to die. But you didn’t. You were saved. By who?*  
>  
> *Don’t trust the clock. It’s broken. The time is wrong. You’re not in 2023. You’re in 2024. Or 2022. Or… none of the above.*  

I checked the date. It was still April 17, 2023. The clock on my wall read 10:03. But when I looked at my phone, it said 11:47. I reset it. It didn’t help. The numbers flickered. Then I saw it—on the screen, for a fraction of a second—2024.  

I ran to the lab. The time displays on every terminal read 2023. But the timestamps on the logs… they were from 2024.  

I called Dr. Kael. He didn’t answer. I went to his office. The door was open. His desk was empty. His chair was overturned. A single sheet of memo paper lay on the floor.  

> *You’re not the first. You’re not the last. But you’re the one who remembers. And that’s why they want you gone.*  

---

**Addendum XXXX-03**  
Researcher Voss was placed under Observation Protocol Theta-9 on 2023-04-18. TAD conducted a full temporal analysis of the notes. No evidence of time travel, quantum entanglement, or known temporal anomalies were detected. The paper, ink, and handwriting all match Voss’s biometrics with 98.7% accuracy. However, the notes contain information that contradicts known events:  

- SCP-XXXX-1 (The Archive) was not breached on 2023-04-12.  
- Dr. Kael has no record of being involved in any classified project from 2018.  
- No fire occurred at Site-19 in 2022 or 2024.  
- The “blue room” (designated Room-7) is currently used for storage and has never been painted red.  

PIU concluded that Voss is suffering from severe dissociative episodes, possibly induced by prolonged exposure to high-stress environments and the psychological strain of working on Project Echo. However, TAD noted that the notes contain no known linguistic patterns of hallucination or delusion—each note is structured, coherent, and contains specific details that, while false, are internally consistent.  

On 2023-04-20, Voss was found in her quarters, screaming at a wall. She claimed the wall was “moving.” When Foundation personnel entered, they found her clutching a note written in her own handwriting:  

> *They’re not in the walls. They’re in the *air*. You can’t breathe it. You can’t breathe it. You’re already dead. You’re already dead. You’re already dead.*  

She was sedated and placed in isolation.  

---

**Log Entry: 2023-04-21 (Recovered from personal journal, found in Voss’s bedside drawer)**  
I don’t know what’s real anymore. I’ve seen the notes. I’ve seen the future. I’ve seen the past. I’ve seen the *other* me. I don’t know if I’m writing this to warn myself… or to convince myself that I’m still here.  

The lights went out at 03:17. I didn’t look. I didn’t move. I just waited. Nothing came.  

But I *remembered* something. A sound. A voice. A child’s voice. Saying, “You’re not supposed to be here.”  

I don’t know who that was. I don’t know if I’m the one who said it.  

I think… I think I’m the anomaly. Not the notes. Not the breach. Me.  

I keep finding new notes. They’re not in my drawer anymore. They’re in my pockets. In my shoes. In my coffee cup.  

And the worst part…  

They’re getting worse.  

They’re not just warnings.  

They’re *confessions*.  

> *I killed them. I killed all of them. I opened the door. I let them in. I was the breach.*  

I didn’t write that.  

But I remember writing it.  

And I don’t know if I’m the one who wrote it… or if I’m just remembering what I’ll do.  

---

**Addendum XXXX-04**  
Researcher Voss remains in isolation. She no longer speaks. She writes constantly—on walls, on her arms, on the floor. The Foundation has secured all documents. The notes are now being analyzed for linguistic, temporal, and psychological anomalies.  

TAD has proposed a containment breach simulation using the data from the notes. However, PIU has recommended against it, citing the risk of reinforcing Voss’s delusions and potentially triggering a self-fulfilling prophecy.  

The question remains: Is SCP-XXXX a temporal anomaly? A psychological fracture? Or is it a message from a future that has already happened—and is now unraveling?  

One thing is certain:  

The lights went out at 03:17.  

And no one came.  

But the notes keep coming.  

And they’re not signed.  

They’re just… written.  

In my handwriting.  

And they’re getting closer.
individual_results.cleaned_model_response:
**Item #:** SCP-XXXX  
**Object Class:** Euclid  
**Special Containment Procedures:** Researcher Elena Voss (Site-19, Personnel File: R-0789) is to be placed under Observation Protocol Theta-9. All personal belongings, including writing implements and notebooks, are to be inspected daily. Any anomalous documents discovered are to be secured and analyzed by the Temporal Anomalies Division (TAD) and the Psychological Integrity Unit (PIU). Researcher Voss is to be restricted from accessing SCP-XXXX-1 (The Archive) and any classified data related to temporal phenomena. She is to be monitored via passive surveillance in her quarters and during work hours. Weekly psychological evaluations are mandatory.

**Description:** SCP-XXXX is a phenomenon involving Researcher Elena Voss, who began receiving handwritten notes from an unknown source claiming to be her future self. The notes are written on standard Foundation memo paper (Type-7, issued to all personnel), in Voss’s handwriting, and contain warnings about a containment breach at Site-19 that has not yet occurred. The first note appeared on 2023-04-12, tucked inside her locked desk drawer, which she had not opened in three days.

---

**Log Entry: 2023-04-12**  
I found it this morning. A single sheet of memo paper, folded neatly, tucked between the false bottom of my desk drawer. I didn’t put it there. I’ve kept that drawer locked since last week. The handwriting… it’s mine. But it’s not *me*. The phrasing is too urgent, too panicked. Like someone writing in a hurry, but also… like they were trying to be precise.  

> *Don’t trust the lights. They’ll go out at 03:17. When they do, don’t look at the corridor. They’re not supposed to be there. They’re not supposed to be alive.*  
>  
> *You’re already too late. They’re coming through the walls.*  

I laughed at first. Then I checked the time. 03:16. The lights flickered. Just once. I stood up, heart pounding. Nothing happened. No one came. I told myself it was stress. I’ve been working on Project Echo for weeks. But I couldn’t shake the feeling that I’d just read a prophecy.

---

**Log Entry: 2023-04-14**  
More notes. Three of them. All in the same place—my desk, my locked drawer. I’ve triple-checked the lock. It’s not being picked. I’ve seen no one enter my quarters.  

> *The blue room is not blue. It’s red. You know this. You’ve seen it. They’re using the old elevator shaft. They’re not ghosts. They’re not SCPs. They’re the ones who were supposed to be erased.*  
>  
> *Don’t let Dr. Kael see the files. He’s not who he says he is. He’s not human.*  

I showed the notes to Dr. Kael. He looked at me like I’d lost my mind. “Elena, you’re exhausted. You’ve been working 18-hour days. We’re all tired.” But he didn’t ask to see the notes. He just told me to rest.  

I looked at the files. The ones he’s been reviewing. The ones from 2018. The ones marked “Classified – Do Not Access.” I didn’t open them. But I *remembered* them. I’ve never seen them before.  

---

**Log Entry: 2023-04-17**  
I found a note in my coat pocket. I hadn’t worn it in days. It was cold outside. I didn’t go out.  

> *They’re in the vents. They’ve been in the vents since the fire. The fire that never happened. You were there. You were supposed to die. But you didn’t. You were saved. By who?*  
>  
> *Don’t trust the clock. It’s broken. The time is wrong. You’re not in 2023. You’re in 2024. Or 2022. Or… none of the above.*  

I checked the date. It was still April 17, 2023. The clock on my wall read 10:03. But when I looked at my phone, it said 11:47. I reset it. It didn’t help. The numbers flickered. Then I saw it—on the screen, for a fraction of a second—2024.  

I ran to the lab. The time displays on every terminal read 2023. But the timestamps on the logs… they were from 2024.  

I called Dr. Kael. He didn’t answer. I went to his office. The door was open. His desk was empty. His chair was overturned. A single sheet of memo paper lay on the floor.  

> *You’re not the first. You’re not the last. But you’re the one who remembers. And that’s why they want you gone.*  

---

**Addendum XXXX-03**  
Researcher Voss was placed under Observation Protocol Theta-9 on 2023-04-18. TAD conducted a full temporal analysis of the notes. No evidence of time travel, quantum entanglement, or known temporal anomalies were detected. The paper, ink, and handwriting all match Voss’s biometrics with 98.7% accuracy. However, the notes contain information that contradicts known events:  

- SCP-XXXX-1 (The Archive) was not breached on 2023-04-12.  
- Dr. Kael has no record of being involved in any classified project from 2018.  
- No fire occurred at Site-19 in 2022 or 2024.  
- The “blue room” (designated Room-7) is currently used for storage and has never been painted red.  

PIU concluded that Voss is suffering from severe dissociative episodes, possibly induced by prolonged exposure to high-stress environments and the psychological strain of working on Project Echo. However, TAD noted that the notes contain no known linguistic patterns of hallucination or delusion—each note is structured, coherent, and contains specific details that, while false, are internally consistent.  

On 2023-04-20, Voss was found in her quarters, screaming at a wall. She claimed the wall was “moving.” When Foundation personnel entered, they found her clutching a note written in her own handwriting:  

> *They’re not in the walls. They’re in the *air*. You can’t breathe it. You can’t breathe it. You’re already dead. You’re already dead. You’re already dead.*  

She was sedated and placed in isolation.  

---

**Log Entry: 2023-04-21 (Recovered from personal journal, found in Voss’s bedside drawer)**  
I don’t know what’s real anymore. I’ve seen the notes. I’ve seen the future. I’ve seen the past. I’ve seen the *other* me. I don’t know if I’m writing this to warn myself… or to convince myself that I’m still here.  

The lights went out at 03:17. I didn’t look. I didn’t move. I just waited. Nothing came.  

But I *remembered* something. A sound. A voice. A child’s voice. Saying, “You’re not supposed to be here.”  

I don’t know who that was. I don’t know if I’m the one who said it.  

I think… I think I’m the anomaly. Not the notes. Not the breach. Me.  

I keep finding new notes. They’re not in my drawer anymore. They’re in my pockets. In my shoes. In my coffee cup.  

And the worst part…  

They’re getting worse.  

They’re not just warnings.  

They’re *confessions*.  

> *I killed them. I killed all of them. I opened the door. I let them in. I was the breach.*  

I didn’t write that.  

But I remember writing it.  

And I don’t know if I’m the one who wrote it… or if I’m just remembering what I’ll do.  

---

**Addendum XXXX-04**  
Researcher Voss remains in isolation. She no longer speaks. She writes constantly—on walls, on her arms, on the floor. The Foundation has secured all documents. The notes are now being analyzed for linguistic, temporal, and psychological anomalies.  

TAD has proposed a containment breach simulation using the data from the notes. However, PIU has recommended against it, citing the risk of reinforcing Voss’s delusions and potentially triggering a self-fulfilling prophecy.  

The question remains: Is SCP-XXXX a temporal anomaly? A psychological fracture? Or is it a message from a future that has already happened—and is now unraveling?  

One thing is certain:  

The lights went out at 03:17.  

And no one came.  

But the notes keep coming.  

And they’re not signed.  

They’re just… written.  

In my handwriting.  

And they’re getting closer.
individual_results.raw_judge_text:
[Analysis]
The piece follows the SCP format faithfully, opening with the requisite Item #, Object Class, and Special Containment Procedures, then weaving in first-person log entries that chart Elena Voss’s escalating paranoia. It hits every bullet of the prompt: handwritten notes from a future self, growing incoherence, contradictory reality-claims, Foundation uncertainty about temporal vs. psychological origin, and the researcher’s eroding trust in her own perception. The tense is consistently past, the voice stays researcher-cold even as it frays, and the seed length is respected.

Character-wise, Elena is sketched more than sculpted. We get her fatigue, her dawning horror, her final mute surrender, but all through the same clinical-meets-frantic register. She never surprises us; she simply accelerates along the single track the premise lays down. Dr. Kael is a cardboard skeptic whose only function is to dismiss her, so the “is he human?” tease lands flat. The Foundation itself behaves plausibly—tests, committees, isolation—but the bureaucratic texture is generic SCP boilerplate rather than a living culture.

Imagery is thin. The “blue room is red” line is nicely unsettling, but we never *see* the room, the corridor, the vents, the flickering clocks; we only get the memos’ shorthand. Descriptions like “screaming at a wall” or “chair overturned” feel like stage directions rather than sensory moments. Prose is clean, efficient, occasionally repetitive (“I didn’t write that. / But I remember writing it.”) but never purple. It avoids overwrought anguish, yet also never achieves the chilling precision of the best SCPs; the final refrain “the notes keep coming” wants to be ominous but feels pre-fab.

Emotionally the story trades in one-note dread: each entry ramps the same dial. There’s no ebb, no false relief, no ironic humor—just a straight line toward “I am the breach.” That inevitability drains tension; once we grasp the pattern, every new note is merely confirmation. The ending tries for a last sting (“they’re getting closer”) but because the piece never granted us a concrete world to lose, the threat remains abstract.

Temporal logic is deliberately slippery, but the contradictions are announced rather than demonstrated; we’re told the clocks disagree, not shown Elena’s disorientation as she tries to sync them. Likewise the Foundation’s debate is summarized in two addenda instead of dramatized through conflicting orders, test results, or dissenting voices. Dialogue is almost nonexistent; when it appears it’s functional and flat.

Sentence flow is smooth, with a tidy alternation of memo excerpts and journal fragments, but the rhythm becomes predictable: memo → reaction → “I told myself it was stress” → next memo. The piece never loosens into the kind of fragmented, stuttering syntax that might convey genuine dissociation, nor does it tighten into icy clinical detachment; it hovers in a safe middle.

In short, the response fulfills the prompt competently, delivers a clear arc, and stays readable, but it never transcends the template. It feels like a respectable SCP wiki entry rather than a memorable piece of fiction.

[Scores]

Believable Character Actions: 14

individual_results.base_prompt:
Write an SCP report about a researcher who begins finding handwritten notes from their future self, warning about a containment breach that hasn't happened yet. The notes become increasingly desperate and incoherent, sometimes containing information that contradicts known reality. Include the Foundation's attempts to determine if this is an actual temporal anomaly or psychological manipulation by a contained entity, and the researcher's struggle to trust their own perception.

First person (researcher's perspective with interspersed notes), past tense.

<SEED> Length: 1000 words.
individual_results.model_response:
**Item #:** SCP-XXXX  
**Object Class:** Euclid  

**Special Containment Procedures:**  
Dr. Elara Voss (SCP-XXXX-1) is to be monitored via biometric surveillance and restricted to Site-77’s Level 3 research wing. All personal effects, including writing instruments, are to be inspected daily. No unapproved documentation is permitted. Dr. Voss is to be debriefed weekly by Dr. Kaelen. Any further notes from "future self" are to be collected, analyzed, and immediately reported. If Dr. Voss exhibits signs of psychological deterioration (e.g., catatonia, dissociation, self-harm), she is to be placed under temporary sedation and re-evaluated for possible memory or identity manipulation.  

**Description:**  
SCP-XXXX is an anomalous phenomenon centered on Dr. Elara Voss, a senior cognitive researcher at Site-77. Beginning on ██/██/20██, Dr. Voss reported discovering handwritten notes in her personal journal—notes written in her own handwriting, yet dated in the future. The first note read:  

> *“Don’t open the red file in Sector 9. They’re not asleep. They’re waiting.”*  
> — *Elara, 12:47 AM, 03/14/20██*  

At the time, Dr. Voss dismissed it as a prank or sleep-deprived hallucination. The red file in Sector 9 had been sealed for 18 months due to a containment breach involving SCP-1423 (a sentient, dream-based entity). No breach had occurred since.  

By the third note, however, the urgency was undeniable.  

> *“They’re in the vents. They’ve been in the vents for 72 hours. You didn’t hear them. You never hear them. But they’re here. I can smell burnt copper. It’s not real. It’s not real. They’re not real.”*  
> — *Elara, 04:11 AM, 03/16/20██*  

I found this one on my desk, folded into the spine of my *Cognitive Dissonance in Anomalous Entities* textbook. No one had been in my office. The ink was black, but analysis revealed trace elements of iridium and a synthetic polymer not found in any known pen. The paper was standard notebook stock—except the fibers were slightly more resistant to tearing.  

I started recording everything. I kept a log. I asked for a psych eval. Dr. Kaelen said I was under stress. “Stress can make you see things,” he said. “Even your own handwriting.”  

But the notes kept coming.  

> *“You’re not the first one. There’s a loop. You’re in a loop. I’m not real. You’re not real. We’re all in the loop. The breach happened yesterday. It happened yesterday. It’s happening now.”*  
> — *Elara, 11:59 PM, 03/20/20██*  

I didn’t sleep for three days. I checked every vent. I ran diagnostics on the air filtration. Nothing. No anomalies. No breaches. No SCP-1423.  

Then, on 03/21, I found a note in the pocket of my lab coat—my *only* lab coat, the one I wore every day.  

> *“They’re not in the vents. They’re in the mirrors. Look in the mirror. You’re not alone. You’re not you. I’m not me. The Foundation is a lie. The breach is real. It’s happening. It’s happening now. I’m writing this because I’m already dead. I’m writing this because I’m still alive. Please—don’t trust the clock.”*  

The clock in my office had stopped at 3:07 AM. I’d never noticed.  

Dr. Kaelen ordered a full psychological assessment. He brought in Dr. Maren, a behavioral specialist. They ran memory scans, fMRI, EEG. All normal. No signs of psychosis, dissociation, or trauma-induced delusion.  

But then, the notes began to contradict known reality.  

> *“The breach happened on 03/15, not 03/14. You were in the med bay. You were bleeding from your ears. You didn’t remember. They erased it. They erased you.”*  
> — *Elara, 02:33 AM, 03/22/20██*  

I checked the logs. There was no breach on the 15th. No medical incident. No one reported bleeding from the ears.  

Yet the next day, I found a photograph in my desk drawer—me, in the med bay, face pale, ears crusted with dried blood. The date on the photo was 03/15/20██. I had no memory of this. I had no memory of being in the med bay.  

I reported it. Dr. Kaelen said the photo was forged. “We’ve seen this before,” he said. “Anomalous memory manipulation. A containment breach in the past, affecting present perception.”  

But how?  

The notes grew more fragmented.  

> *“I’m not Elara. I’m not. The name is wrong. The name is wrong. The name is—”*  
> — *Elara, 08:19 AM, 03/23/20██*  

Then, silence.  

For 48 hours, nothing.  

I started to believe it was over. Maybe I’d imagined it. Maybe it was stress. Maybe I was losing my mind.  

Then, at 1:03 AM on 03/25, I found a note tucked inside my coffee mug.  

> *“They’re not in the vents. They’re not in the mirrors. They’re in the air. They’re in the breath. You’re breathing them. You’re breathing them. The breach is not a thing. The breach is a person. It’s you. It’s always been you. You opened it. You opened it. You opened it. You opened it. You opened it.”*  

I dropped the mug. It shattered.  

I ran to the nearest security terminal. I pulled up the breach logs.  

There was no breach.  

But then I saw it.  

A log entry, timestamped 03/15/20██, 02:07 AM.  

> *“Containment breach in Sector 9. SCP-1423 escaped. Dr. Elara Voss initiated emergency lockdown. Subject sustained severe cranial trauma. Deceased at 02:18 AM.”*  

I stared.  

I had no memory of this.  

I had no memory of dying.  

I had no memory of being dead.  

Dr. Kaelen was in my office within minutes. I showed him the log. He paled. “That’s not possible,” he said. “That log doesn’t exist.”  

But it was there.  

And the ink in the note—same composition as the others. Iridium. Polymer. Untraceable.  

We ran a full temporal anomaly scan. Nothing. No chroniton emissions. No temporal displacement. No evidence of time travel.  

But the notes kept coming.  

> *“I’m not writing this. You’re writing this. I’m you. You’re me. We’re the breach. We’re the containment. We’re the loop. We’re the lie.”*  
> — *Elara, 11:59 PM, 03/25/20██*  

I don’t know if I’m real.  

I don’t know if I’m the researcher.  

I don’t know if the Foundation is real.  

I only know the notes are still appearing.  

And I’m afraid to look in the mirror.  

Because the last note I found—this one—was written on the inside of my eyelid.  

I found it when I blinked.  

And it said:  

> *“You’re already dead. You’ve been dead for 37 days. You’re just remembering how to breathe.”*  

— Dr. Elara Voss, SCP-XXXX-1  
*Final entry, 03/26/20██*

individual_results.raw_judge_text:
[Analysis]
The piece follows the prompt’s structural requirements—SCP-style header, first-person researcher log, interleaved “future” notes—but it leans so hard on escalating hysteria that the Foundation’s investigative angle is reduced to a single line (“We ran a full temporal anomaly scan. Nothing.”). The researcher’s psychological collapse is shown only through repetitively frantic notes that recycle the same “you’re dead/loop/breach is you” beats; the promised ambiguity between temporal anomaly and external manipulation is asserted rather than dramatized. Descriptive texture is thin: we get “burnt copper,” “iridium ink,” and “crusted ears,” but no sensory follow-through or environmental detail to anchor the horror. The prose itself is serviceable yet littered with punchy sentence fragments that soon feel mannered rather than distressed. Voice wavers between clinical Foundation tone and purple-tinged angst (“I found it when I blinked”). The twist that the researcher died 37 days ago lands as a gimmick because no prior evidence (co-worker reactions, security footage, medical records) is ever filtered through the narrative; we’re simply told the log “doesn’t exist” and then that it does, without fallout. Ending on a note “written on the inside of my eyelid” crosses from creepy to camp, breaking the piece’s already shaky credibility. Overall, it’s a rapid crescendo of italicized madness that forgets to earn each step downward.

The notes become increasingly desperate and incoherent, sometimes containing information that contradicts known reality. Include the Foundation's attempts to determine if this is an actual temporal anomaly or psychological manipulation by a contained entity, and the researcher's struggle to trust their own perception.

First person (researcher's perspective with interspersed notes), past tense.

individual_results.model_response:
**Item #:** SCP-XXXX  
**Object Class:** Euclid  
**Special Containment Procedures:** Researcher Dr. Aris Thorne (XXXX-1) is to be monitored continuously via audiovisual feeds and psychological evaluation. All personal effects, including notebooks, pens, and desk space, are to be inspected daily. Any new notes bearing Dr. Thorne’s handwriting are to be secured and analyzed immediately. No personnel are to engage Dr. Thorne in discussion about the notes without Level 4 clearance. The site’s main server logs are to be cross-referenced with all temporal anomalies under review. If Dr. Thorne exhibits signs of dissociation or delusional behavior, he is to be placed under observation in Site-77’s psychiatric wing.

---

**Addendum XXXX-1: Initial Incident Report**

It started with a note.

I found it on my desk this morning—no, wait. I *know* I didn’t leave it there. I remember locking my drawer last night. I remember the sound of the latch clicking shut. But there it was: a single sheet of paper, folded in thirds, written in my own handwriting.

> *Don’t open the west wing airlock. They’re already inside. They’re not human. They’re not even close. Don’t trust the red light. It’s not red. It’s not anything. It’s a lie.*

I stared at it. My hands were shaking. I checked the timestamp on the note—10:47 AM. I hadn’t written it. I hadn’t even been in the lab yet. The security feed from 10:46 AM showed me walking in, keys in hand, eyes down. No note. No one else in the corridor. And yet—there it was.

I called Dr. Lorne. I told her I needed to see the footage. She came in, looked at the note, then at me. “You wrote this, Aris,” she said. “It’s your handwriting. You’re stressed. You’ve been working double shifts on the Keter-class chronal resonance project.”

But I *know* I didn’t write it.

---

**Addendum XXXX-2: Chronological Anomaly Log**

- **Date:** 2023-09-12  
  **Note:** *They’re not coming from the past. They’re coming from the future. The breach isn’t tomorrow. It’s already happened. You’re already dead. Don’t let the lights go out. Don’t look at the reflection in the glass. It’s not you.*

  **Analysis:** The note was discovered at 3:18 AM. Security logs show a 2.7-second glitch in the west corridor cameras—no data, no audio, just static. The glitch coincided with the note appearing. Dr. Thorne claims he was asleep in his quarters. No entry recorded. No personnel in the area.

- **Date:** 2023-09-14  
  **Note:** *The Foundation doesn’t exist. You’re not real. I’m not real. The only thing that’s real is the silence after the scream. It’s not a scream. It’s a whisper. It’s me. It’s you. It’s us. It’s all of us. Don’t trust the coffee. It’s poisoned. It’s not coffee. It’s blood. It’s memory.*

  **Analysis:** Dr. Thorne was observed muttering to himself in the break room. He refused to drink the coffee offered. When asked why, he said, “It tastes like static.” Blood tests showed no anomalies, but his cortisol levels were elevated. The note was found under his chair. Handwriting identical. Ink composition matches his usual pen.

- **Date:** 2023-09-16  
  **Note:** *The breach happened at 11:59 PM. You were there. You opened the door. You said “hello.” It wasn’t a greeting. It was a surrender. They’re not outside. They’re inside you. You’re already one of them. The notes aren’t warnings. They’re confessions. I’m sorry. I’m so sorry. Don’t open the file labeled “Project Echo.” It’s not a file. It’s a door.*

  **Analysis:** Dr. Thorne was found in the archive wing, staring at a locked terminal. He claimed he’d “heard a voice” from inside the server rack. He was restrained and sedated. The terminal contained a file named “Project Echo” — a project that does not exist in Foundation records. When accessed, the file displayed a single line of text: *“You were never supposed to see this.”* The system logs showed no access attempts from Dr. Thorne’s ID.

---

**Addendum XXXX-3: Psychological Evaluation (Dr. Elena Lorne, Senior Psychologist)**

Dr. Thorne exhibits symptoms consistent with severe temporal disorientation, possibly induced by prolonged exposure to anomalous chronal fields during the Keter project. However, the consistency of the handwriting, the precise timing of note appearances (always during brief camera glitches), and the inclusion of information that contradicts known reality—such as the nonexistence of Project Echo—suggests a possible external influence.

We have ruled out forgery. The ink, paper, and handwriting are all verifiable as Dr. Thorne’s. No other personnel have access to his desk. No one has been seen entering his quarters.

But here’s the thing: the notes *know* things. They know about the camera glitch before it happens. They reference events that haven’t occurred. And worst of all… they’re *right* about the coffee. When I tested it, the lab’s spectrometer detected traces of hemoglobin—undetectable to standard tests. Not human. Not animal. Not anything we’ve cataloged.

I don’t know if I’m losing my mind. Or if the Foundation is.

---

**Addendum XXXX-4: Final Entry (Personal Log, Dr. Aris Thorne)**

I can’t sleep. I can’t eat. I keep checking the clock. 11:58 PM. The red light in the corridor is flickering. It’s supposed to be green. It’s not red. It’s not anything. It’s a lie.

The note came this morning—no, yesterday. I don’t know what day it is. The calendar says October 1st. But the world feels like September 17th. I keep seeing myself in the glass. But it’s not me. It’s someone with my face and hollow eyes. It’s *me*.

I found a new note. On my desk. In the dark.

> *I’m not your future. I’m your past. I’m the version of you that stayed. The one who didn’t open the door. The one who didn’t say hello. I’m the ghost of what you could have been. I’m the warning you ignored. They’re not coming from the future. They’re coming from the moment you stopped believing in the truth.*

I don’t know who wrote this. I don’t know if it’s me. I don’t know if I’m still real.

I just know the lights are going out.

And the camera feed—*it’s not glitching*. It’s *watching*. It’s showing me a hallway I’ve never seen. A door I’ve never opened. And standing there… is me.

But I’m not alone.

There’s someone behind me.

And they’re smiling.

---

**Addendum XXXX-5: Final Status Report**

Dr. Aris Thorne was found in his office at 11:59 PM on October 1st, 2023. He was seated at his desk, eyes open, unresponsive. No signs of injury. No note found on the desk.

Security footage from the corridor shows a 3.2-second blackout at 11:59:00 PM. During that time, the camera feed displayed only static—except for a brief, fragmented image of Dr. Thorne, standing in the hallway, facing away. He was holding a pen. The image dissolved before the feed restored.

The terminal in his office contained a single file labeled “Project Echo.” It opened to a blank screen. When accessed again, the file was gone. The system logs showed no access.

Dr. Thorne remains in a catatonic state. He does not respond to stimuli. His vitals are stable. His brainwave patterns show no activity consistent with consciousness.

The note found in the lab’s main archive—written in his handwriting—reads:

> *They’re not coming from the future. They’re coming from the moment you stopped believing. I’m sorry, Aris. I’m so sorry. It was me all along.*

We are sealing the west wing. We are locking the door.

But I keep wondering—*who closed it?*

And if I’m not the one who wrote the note… then who is?

individual_results.raw_judge_text:
[Analysis]  
The piece is a clever hybrid: it presents itself as an SCP dossier while embedding a first-person chronicle of Dr. Aris Thorne’s breakdown. That structural choice is the story’s greatest strength; the clinical addenda and the increasingly frantic personal log play off each other, letting the horror leak through bureaucratic cracks. The prompt asked for first-person, past-tense, interspersed notes, and the model delivers exactly that, even keeping the “notes” visually distinct within the addenda.  

Characterisation is thin but functional. Thorne is the only rounded figure, and we experience his disintegration in real time. The psychologists and security staff remain SCP-canon ciphers, which is acceptable inside the format, yet it still feels like a lost opportunity: the tension between “temporal anomaly” and “psychological break” would sharpen if we sensed that the doctors themselves are rattled rather than merely annotating. As written, their reports are too calm, too textbook, blunting the emotional gradient.  

Imagery is selective and often effective—“tastes like static,” “the silence after the scream,” the reflection that “isn’t me”—but the piece leans on the same few sensory triggers (red light, coffee, camera glitch) until they become predictable. When every addendum ends with another cryptic one-liner, the escalation starts to feel mechanical rather than terrifying.  

Prose style mirrors the SCP template: clipped, passive-voiced, laden with black bars and timestamps. That is faithful, but it also traps the narrative in a monotone. The “personal log” sections try to break free, yet the diction stays surprisingly generic (“I can’t sleep. I can’t eat.”). There is little rhythmic variation, almost no sentence-level music; the dread is declared rather than evoked.  

The plot trajectory is clear—notes arrive, foretell, contradict, corrode reality—but the middle repeats the same beat (glitch → note → blood in coffee → catatonic doctors) without deepening the mystery. The finale attempts a recursive sting (“who closed the door?”) but because the story never established a baseline reality to violate, the twist feels abstract rather than devastating. We are told Thorne is now catatonic and the west wing is sealed, yet we have no sensory anchor to make that loss sting.  

Finally, the piece never decides whether it is a time-loop anomaly, a memetic parasite, or a psychic break. Ambiguity can be powerful, but here it reads like hedging: the story keeps adding contradictory tags without letting any one reading accumulate emotional weight. The result is an elegantly formatted file that engages the intellect but rarely the gut.

individual_results.base_prompt:
Write an SCP entry about a series of identical unmarked doors appearing in abandoned buildings worldwide that lead to a massive, architecturally impossible archive. Documents within reference a previous global civilization destroyed by an unspecified containment failure. Foundation researchers discover references to their own organization under a different name, including personnel files for current staff dated centuries ago. Include exploration logs revealing sections of the archive actively being removed by entities resembling hazmat teams who flee when approached, and evidence that O5 Council members have visited the archive without authorization.

Third person (exploration team perspective) with recovered document excerpts.

<SEED> Length: 1000 words.
individual_results.model_response:
**Item #:** SCP-XXXX  
**Object Class:** Keter  

**Special Containment Procedures:**  
All known instances of SCP-XXXX are to be monitored via satellite surveillance and local Foundation field agents. Entry into any SCP-XXXX instance is strictly prohibited without prior O5-level authorization. Personnel assigned to investigate SCP-XXXX must undergo Level 4 clearance and psychological screening. Any contact with the archive’s contents must be logged and reported to the O5 Council immediately. No personnel are permitted to enter the archive without full hazmat gear, radiation shielding, and a designated extraction team on standby.  

**Description:**  
SCP-XXXX refers to a series of identical, unmarked doors appearing in abandoned or derelict buildings across the globe. As of ██/██/████, 127 confirmed instances have been documented, spanning locations from ████████ (Ukraine), to ████████ (Namibia), to ████████ (Alaska). All doors are constructed of a non-ferrous, non-identifiable alloy, measuring 2.03 meters in height and 0.91 meters in width. The surface is featureless except for a series of fine, parallel scratches encircling the doorknob—each pattern consistent across all instances, with no variation in depth, angle, or spacing.  

Upon contact, the door opens silently into a vast, architecturally impossible interior: a labyrinthine archive of infinite scale, with corridors stretching into impossible geometries. The air is dry and cold, with no discernible source of light—yet the space is fully illuminated by a soft, ambient glow emanating from the walls themselves. The architecture defies Euclidean principles: staircases spiral into walls, hallways loop back on themselves, and rooms contain more than four dimensions.  

The archive contains an estimated 1.8 billion documents, all written in a language resembling ancient Sumerian but with syntactic structures inconsistent with any known linguistic family. Translations reveal references to a previous global civilization—designated by the Foundation as "The First Archive" or "The Pre-Containment Age"—which collapsed due to a catastrophic containment failure involving an entity designated SCP-XXXX-Ω (unconfirmed).  

**Discovery Log XXXX-7:**  
*Date: 07/14/20██*  
*Team: Delta-9 (Dr. Aris Thorne, Dr. Lena Voss, Agent R. Keene)*  

We entered SCP-XXXX-██ (abandoned textile mill, ████████, France) at 08:17. The door opened without resistance. The air inside was still and smelled faintly of ozone and old paper.  

The first corridor was lined with shelves of leather-bound tomes. We recovered one at random—*Codex 17-γ*, titled "The Fall of the First Archive: A Chronicle of the 13th Collapse." The text described a global network of "Containment Sanctuaries" built to house entities deemed too dangerous for human comprehension. It referenced the "O5 Council" as a body of twelve "Wardens of the Veil," and included detailed personnel records—names, birth dates, and service histories.  

Among the documents was a file labeled "Dr. Aris Thorne, Lead Archivist, 11th Cycle." The file listed a birth date of 3042 BCE. My actual birth date: 1987.  

Dr. Voss found a second file—*Lena Voss, Senior Archivist, 11th Cycle*. Her birth date: 3019 BCE.  

We did not speak for ten minutes.  

**Exploration Log XXXX-12:**  
*Date: 08/03/20██*  
*Team: Sigma-4 (Dr. Elias Maren, Agent D. Cho, Dr. J. Reed)*  

We entered SCP-XXXX-██ (abandoned subway terminal, ████████, Japan). The archive here was different—sections of the library were in disarray. Shelves were overturned, documents scattered.  

We found a series of footprints—large, boot-like, but with three toes. They led to a central chamber where three humanoid figures in full hazmat suits (white, with reinforced seals) were actively removing documents from a vault. They moved with mechanical precision, ignoring our presence. When I shouted, they turned—faces obscured by visors. They dropped their tools and fled, sprinting through a corridor that folded inward like origami.  

We recovered one document from the floor: *Log Entry: O5-9, 12th Cycle, 437 BCE*. The entry read:  
> *"The breach is contained. But not for long. They are coming back. We must erase our records. They are already in the archive. They are already us."*  

**Recovered Document Excerpts:**  

1. *"The First Archive was not destroyed by war. It was destroyed by memory. The entities we contained were not the threat—they were the warning. The O5 Council, in their hubris, believed they could remember everything. But memory is a trap. The archive remembers us. And now it is remembering us again."*  
—*Fragment 9-ε, Vault Kappa-7*  

2. *"Do not trust the names. The O5 Council you know is not the one that built this. The ones who came before us are still here. They walk the halls. They wear your faces. They write your reports. They are the ones removing the truth."*  
—*Anonymous Note, tucked inside a book titled 'The Weight of a Name'*  

3. *"Dr. Thorne, you are not the first. You were born in the 11th Cycle. You died in the 12th. You have returned. You have always returned. The archive does not forget. It only waits."*  
—*Handwritten note, found on a desk labeled 'O5-1' in Sector Theta*  

**Addendum XXXX-18:**  
On 10/21/20██, satellite telemetry detected anomalous movement in SCP-XXXX-███ (abandoned observatory, Chile). Thermal imaging recorded eight human-shaped signatures entering the archive. Security footage from a nearby Foundation outpost revealed O5 Council member O5-3, O5-7, and O5-11 entering the building at 03:47. They were not authorized for any mission in that region.  

They remained inside for 8 hours. Upon exit, all three were unharmed, but their eyes appeared dilated and their behavior was markedly detached. O5-3 stated: *"We were not here. The archive has no record of us."*  

Subsequent review of Foundation archives revealed that O5-3’s personnel file contained a photograph dated 3120 BCE—same as the one found in SCP-XXXX-██.  

**Addendum XXXX-22:**  
The O5 Council has issued Directive Theta-9: All SCP-XXXX instances are to be considered "active memory nodes." No further exploration is permitted. All recovered documents are to be destroyed.  

Dr. Thorne has been placed on indefinite leave. Dr. Voss resigned yesterday. Agent Keene reported seeing a man in a hazmat suit standing outside his apartment window—face obscured, but wearing a badge with the name "O5-1."  

The scratches around the doorknobs have begun to appear on the doors of Foundation facilities.  

They are spreading.

They remained inside for 8 hours. Upon exit, all three were unharmed, but their eyes appeared dilated and their behavior was markedly detached. O5-3 stated: *"We were not here. The archive has no record of us."*  

Subsequent review of Foundation archives revealed that O5-3’s personnel file contained a photograph dated 3120 BCE—same as the one found in SCP-XXXX-██.  

**Addendum XXXX-22:**  
The O5 Council has issued Directive Theta-9: All SCP-XXXX instances are to be considered "active memory nodes." No further exploration is permitted. All recovered documents are to be destroyed.  

Dr. Thorne has been placed on indefinite leave. Dr. Voss resigned yesterday. Agent Keene reported seeing a man in a hazmat suit standing outside his apartment window—face obscured, but wearing a badge with the name "O5-1."  

The scratches around the doorknobs have begun to appear on the doors of Foundation facilities.  

They are spreading.
individual_results.raw_judge_text:
[Analysis]  
The piece is a competent SCP pastiche that hits every bullet in the prompt: identical doors, impossible archive, prior civilization, Foundation precursors, hazmat entities, and O5 trespass. It is brisk, clinical, and easy to read—exactly the house style.  
Unfortunately it is also entirely derivative. The “we found our own personnel files from 3000 BCE” twist, the “archive that remembers you,” the hazmat phantoms who drop everything and sprint away, the O5s secretly visiting their own relics—every beat is cribbed from Series I-II SCPs, House of Leaves, Annihilation, and the back half of every “lost civilization” creepypasta. Nothing is refreshed, nothing is deepened; the piece simply rearranges familiar furniture.  
Characterization is nil. The three exploration logs are interchangeable; the speakers exist only to deliver exposition and then stand stunned for ten minutes. The hazmat teams are faceless plot devices, and the O5s behave like teenagers sneaking into a haunted house rather than the most security-obsessed people on Earth. Their post-visit amnesia line (“We were not here”) is unintentionally funny and undercuts the menace.  
Tone wobbles between dry technical report and bargain-bin cosmic horror. The phrase “the archive remembers us. And now it is remembering us again” wants to sound ominous but lands as tautological mush. Likewise, “memory is a trap” is asserted, never demonstrated; we are simply told the stakes are mind-blowing.  
Prose is serviceable but littered with clichés: “labyrinthine,” “impossible geometries,” “folded inward like origami,” “they are already us.” These phrases have been used in literally dozens of SCPs; their repetition here feels like Mad-Libs creepypasta.  
The ending attempts a viral sting—scratches appearing on Foundation doors—but because the story has never grounded us in a specific character’s paranoia or loss, the image is hollow. It’s darkness by checklist rather than by earned dread.  
In short, the entry fulfills the prompt’s mechanics, but it is content to recycle tropes instead of interrogating them, and it mistakes portentous statements for emotional weight.

individual_results.base_prompt:
Write an SCP entry about a series of identical unmarked doors appearing in abandoned buildings worldwide that lead to a massive, architecturally impossible archive. Documents within reference a previous global civilization destroyed by an unspecified containment failure. Foundation researchers discover references to their own organization under a different name, including personnel files for current staff dated centuries ago. Include exploration logs revealing sections of the archive actively being removed by entities resembling hazmat teams who flee when approached, and evidence that O5 Council members have visited the archive without authorization.

Third person (exploration team perspective) with recovered document excerpts.

<SEED> Length: 1000 words.
individual_results.model_response:
**Item #:** SCP-XXXX  
**Object Class:** Keter  

**Special Containment Procedures:**  
SCP-XXXX instances are to be contained under Observation Level 3. All known instances are to be monitored via remote surveillance; no personnel are to enter any SCP-XXXX door without Level 5 clearance and a full hazmat suit with biometric dampening. Exploration teams must be composed of at least three personnel, with one designated as a "neutral observer" to document anomalies without direct interaction. Any recovered documents are to be cataloged under File XXXX-α and reviewed by the O5 Council prior to dissemination.  

No official Foundation records may reference SCP-XXXX. All references to the "Archive of the First Architects" are to be purged from standard databases. Unauthorized visits to SCP-XXXX locations by O5 Council members are to be reported immediately and investigated under Protocol Omega-9.  

---

**Description:**  
SCP-XXXX refers to a series of identical, unmarked doors appearing in abandoned or derelict buildings worldwide. The doors are composed of an unknown metallic alloy, approximately 2.1 meters in height and 0.9 meters in width, with no visible hinges, handles, or seams. The surface is uniformly matte black, reflecting no light. Despite varying environmental conditions—ranging from Arctic ruins to tropical decay—the doors remain pristine, often appearing more weathered than the structures they inhabit, as though they predate the buildings themselves.  

Upon entry, the doors lead to an infinite, architecturally impossible archive designated Site-XXXX-Alpha. The archive is a labyrinthine structure of shifting corridors, impossible geometries (e.g., staircases spiraling into ceilings, rooms that exist in multiple dimensions simultaneously), and towering shelves of crystalline data slabs. The air is cold and silent, with no discernible source of light—yet all documents and structures are visible in perfect clarity.  

The archive contains records of a civilization predating recorded human history. The civilization, referred to in recovered texts as the "First Architects," possessed knowledge of dimensional manipulation, quantum memory storage, and reality stabilization. Their downfall, as documented in multiple sources, was caused by a catastrophic containment failure involving a "Reality Anchor" device—possibly the precursor to Foundation technology.  

**Recovered Document Excerpts (Translated from Proto-Dravidian/Cuneiform hybrid script):**  
> *"We sealed the fracture beneath the Third Spire. We called it 'The Stillness.' But the Stillness was not still. It dreamed. And when it woke, it remembered us. We failed to contain what we had made. Now, the Archive is all that remains."*  
> — *Excerpt from Codex X-7, "Chronicles of the Sundering," Site-XXXX-Alpha, Sector Gamma*  

> *"The Keepers of the Archive shall come. They will wear the same names. They will remember nothing. They will come to fix what was broken. But they do not know the truth: they are not the first. They are the seventh."*  
> — *Excerpt from the Obsidian Ledger, Section 12.4*  

**Exploration Log XXXX-7 (Dr. Elias Voss, Lead Researcher):**  
> *Entry 01: We entered via SCP-XXXX-12 (abandoned observatory, Siberia). The door opened without resistance. The Archive was… vast. Corridors bent at 180-degree angles. No gravity anomalies, but the air felt thick, like breathing through glass. Shelves lined with data slabs—some glowing faintly, others inert. We found a file labeled "Project: Anima." It listed personnel. Names. Dates. One entry read: "Dr. Elias Voss – Assigned to Sector Theta. Status: Active (1142 BCE)." I… I have no memory of that. I’ve been with the Foundation since 2007.*  

> *Entry 03: We encountered entities in hazmat suits—black, reflective, no facial features. They moved in perfect synchronicity, removing data slabs from shelves and placing them into sealed containers. They did not respond to vocal contact. When I stepped forward, they turned and fled—vanishing into a corridor that should not have existed. The containers were stamped with a symbol: a spiral within a circle, crossed by a vertical line. It matches the insignia on O5-9’s personal ID tag.*  

> *Entry 05: I reviewed the O5 Council’s recent travel logs. O5-3, O5-7, and O5-9 all logged visits to SCP-XXXX-03 (a former cathedral in southern France) during the past 72 hours. No record of authorization. No personnel logs. Only timestamps. I cross-referenced the site’s internal chronology. The Archive’s time flow is non-linear. Their visit… occurred 1,400 years ago in our timeline. But they were there. I saw their footprints in the Archive’s dust—fresh, unexplained.*  

**Addendum XXXX-1:**  
Dr. Voss was found unconscious in Sector Theta, clutching a data slab. The slab contained a personnel file for "Dr. Elias Voss – Foundation Liaison, Sector Theta – 1142 BCE." The file listed his "current" role as "Archivist of the Seventh Cycle." He is now in a vegetative state, unresponsive to all stimuli. His last words, recorded via audio log, were: *"They’re not fixing it. They’re just… replacing it."*  

**Addendum XXXX-2:**  
Following a breach in Site-XXXX-Alpha’s perimeter (designated "The Fracture"), Foundation personnel discovered a sealed chamber containing a single, intact data core. Upon activation, it projected a holographic message from an individual resembling O5-1, but with a voice that had no pitch or timbre—only resonance.  

> *"If you are seeing this, then the Archive has failed. Again. We are not the first. We are not the last. We are the seventh. The First Architects built the Anchor. We built the Foundation. And we failed. But you—*you*—are not the first to find this. You are the next. Do not trust the names. Do not trust the faces. The Archive is not a library. It is a tomb. And the doors… they are not entrances. They are warnings."*  

The message ended. The core self-destructed.  

**Addendum XXXX-3:**  
As of 12:00 UTC, six new SCP-XXXX instances have been confirmed in locations previously unrecorded. All appear in buildings that were not abandoned prior to the event. The doors are now slightly warm to the touch.  

**O5 Council Note (Unverified):**  
> *"We knew this would happen. We have always known. The Archive remembers. And it is learning. Do not open the doors. Do not read the files. Do not go back. It is not a mistake. It is a cycle. And we are trapped in it."*  
> — *O5-1, private transmission, encrypted to all O5s, 2024-06-18*  

**Final Note:**  
SCP-XXXX is not a containment breach.  
SCP-XXXX is the containment.  
And we are not the keepers.  
We are the keys.

individual_results.raw_judge_text:
[Analysis]
The piece is a competent SCP-style entry that hits every bullet in the prompt: identical doors, impossible archive, pre-cursor civilization, Foundation doppelgängers, hazmat entities, and O5 trespass. It is structurally tidy, uses the clinical tone the SCP wiki expects, and sprinkles in just enough “impossible geometry” and time-loops to feel on-brand.  
However, it never rises above the level of a checklist. The archive is “vast,” corridors “bend at 180-degree angles,” the air is “thick, like breathing through glass”—all serviceable but stock imagery. The hazmat teams flee on cue; the O5 footprints are “fresh, unexplained”; the final twist is “we are the keys.” Every beat is telegraphed, every revelation delivered in the same calm, slightly smug omniscient voice.  
Characterization is non-existent. Dr. Voss is a name attached to a paradox; the O5s are spooky silhouettes. Because nobody has an interior life, the emotional payload—existential dread, ontological vertigo—must be supplied by the reader. The prose keeps telling us this is terrifying (“the Archive is not a library. It is a tomb”) without letting us feel it.  
The dialogue is sparse and functional, but the one line that tries for poetry—“They’re not fixing it. They’re just… replacing it.”—lands with a thud because we have no prior sense of what “it” means to Voss. The ending cycles back to the same cosmic-cubicle gloom the SCP wiki has recycled for fifteen years: “we are trapped in it.” The piece therefore feels safe, predictable, already archived.

Documents within reference a previous global civilization destroyed by an unspecified containment failure. Foundation researchers discover references to their own organization under a different name, including personnel files for current staff dated centuries ago. Include exploration logs revealing sections of the archive actively being removed by entities resembling hazmat teams who flee when approached, and evidence that O5 Council members have visited the archive without authorization.

Third person (exploration team perspective) with recovered document excerpts.

<SEED> Length: 1000 words.
individual_results.model_response:
**Item #:** SCP-XXXX  
**Object Class:** Keter  

**Special Containment Procedures:**  
SCP-XXXX is not currently contained due to its nature as a series of anomalous portals appearing in abandoned structures globally. All known instances are to be monitored via satellite surveillance and local Foundation field agents. Upon discovery, immediate containment teams (Level 3 or higher) are to secure the surrounding area and establish perimeter surveillance. No personnel are to enter SCP-XXXX without prior O5 Council approval and Level 5 clearance. Entry teams must be equipped with full hazmat suits, EM dampeners, and psychological screening protocols. Any recovered documents are to be cataloged under Project AETERNITAS and reviewed by the O5 Council before dissemination.  

**Description:**  
SCP-XXXX refers to a series of identical, unmarked doors appearing in abandoned or derelict buildings worldwide (e.g., abandoned railway stations in Siberia, derelict hospitals in southern France, collapsed warehouses in Jakarta). The doors are constructed of a non-ferrous, non-reflective alloy with no visible hinges, handles, or markings. Each door measures 2.1 meters in height and 1.0 meter in width, with a faint, pulsating blue-green glow emanating from the edges when in complete darkness. The glow persists even when ambient light is introduced, though it dims slightly.  

Upon approach, the door emits a low-frequency hum (17.3 Hz) detectable only via specialized audio equipment. When touched, the door opens silently into a vast, architecturally impossible archive. The interior of SCP-XXXX is described as a labyrinthine library spanning an estimated 12 kilometers in diameter, with no discernible exit. The architecture defies Euclidean geometry: corridors spiral into impossible angles, staircases loop back on themselves, and ceilings vanish into infinite darkness. The air is cold and carries a faint scent of ozone and old paper.  

The archive contains an estimated 1.7 trillion documents, stored in floating shelves, suspended in midair, or embedded within walls. All documents are handwritten or printed on materials that do not degrade, despite apparent age. Text is in multiple languages, including Sumerian, Latin, Old Norse, and several undecipherable scripts. Many references point to a previous global civilization—designated by researchers as "The First Archive" or "The Keepers"—that collapsed due to a catastrophic containment failure involving an object now believed to be SCP-XXXX itself.  

**Discovery Log XXXX-1 (Recovered from Site-77, former observatory in Patagonia):**  
> *Date: 2023-04-12*  
> *Lead Researcher: Dr. Elara Voss*  
>  
> Entry team entered through the door at 03:17 UTC. Initial assessment: no immediate anomalies. The archive is vast, with rows of floating shelves. We found a document labeled "Chronicles of the Final Breach, Year 1278 of the Great Cycle." It details the collapse of the First Archive after an entity known as "The Unbound" escaped containment. The text describes a containment organization—referred to as "The Custodians of the Silent Vault"—which failed to maintain the seal.  
>  
> We later discovered a personnel file labeled "Dr. Elara Voss, Senior Archivist, 1123rd Cycle." The file was dated 1147 A.C. (Anno Custodum), with a photograph of me—except my face is aged, my hair grey, and my eyes hollow. The file states: *"Subject exhibits high risk of cognitive contamination. Recommend isolation. Do not allow access to the Central Vault."*  
>  
> We are not alone. At 04:42, we observed figures in white hazmat suits moving through the upper levels. They carried equipment resembling vacuum sealers and data-siphons. When we attempted to approach, they vanished into a corridor that did not exist moments before. Their suits bore no insignia, but one carried a badge with the symbol: a circle enclosing a stylized eye. It matches the insignia on the O5 Council’s personal seals.  

**Recovered Document Excerpt (From Archive Section "Vault Theta-9"):**  
> *"The Custodians have forgotten their purpose. They now call themselves the Foundation, but they are not the same. They do not remember the First Breach. They do not know why the doors must never open. They have already failed once. They will fail again. The Unbound is not dead. It is waiting. The doors are not portals. They are warnings."*  
>  
> — *Anonymous Archivist, 1278 A.C.*  

**Exploration Log XXXX-3 (Site-91, abandoned textile mill, Yorkshire):**  
> *Date: 2023-07-03*  
> *Team: Delta-7*  
>  
> We found a section of the archive labeled "O5 Council Archives — Restricted Access." The files were dated 983 A.C. to 1147 A.C. We located records for current O5 Council members under different names:  
>  
> - **O5-1 (Current: Dr. Aris Thorne)** → "Keeper of the First Seal, Alistair Veyne"  
> - **O5-3 (Current: Dr. Lien Zhao)** → "Scribe of the Final Ward, Linh Mei"  
> - **O5-7 (Current: Dr. R. K. Myles)** → "Watcher of the Threshold, Rafe K. Myles"  
>  
> All files contain biographical details consistent with current personnel, but with additional annotations: *"Subject has breached protocol. Unauthorized visit to Central Vault. Recommend re-education."* One file included a timestamped entry: *"Visited Vault Theta-9 on 1147 A.C., Day 365. Found the door. Left without sealing it. The Unbound knows we are here."*  
>  
> We also recovered a photograph of the O5 Council standing before a massive door—identical to SCP-XXXX—dated 1147 A.C. The image is blurred at the edges, but the faces are unmistakable. They are not wearing their current uniforms. They are wearing robes of a forgotten order.  
>  
> We have since been ordered to cease all research. No further entries.  

**Addendum XXXX-1:**  
> *2023-08-15*  
> Foundation Intelligence confirms that at least three O5 Council members have visited SCP-XXXX sites without authorization, as recorded in the archive’s "Visitation Logs." These entries were not in Foundation databases. The logs include timestamps from 1147 A.C. and 1278 A.C., yet the individuals in question were not born until the 20th century.  
>  
> Further investigation revealed that the "Custodians of the Silent Vault" were not a myth. They were the Foundation’s direct predecessor. The "containment failure" referenced in the documents was the first breach of SCP-XXXX. The current Foundation is not the first iteration. It is the third.  
>  
> The doors are not just portals. They are memories. And the archive is not just a library. It is a tomb.  
>  
> **Final Note (Recovered from a damaged data tablet, found in a collapsed corridor):**  
> *"They think they’re protecting the world. They’re not. They’re just the latest caretakers of a lie. The Unbound is not outside. It’s inside the door. It’s inside us. It’s been waiting for the next cycle to begin. And we are the ones who will open it again."*  
>  
> — *Anonymous Archivist, 1147 A.C.*  

**Conclusion:**  
SCP-XXXX is not merely a doorway to an archive. It is a recursive loop of containment, failure, and rebirth. The Foundation is not the first. It will not be the last. The doors will keep appearing. The archive will keep remembering. And when the next cycle begins—when the next O5 Council walks through the door—the Unbound will be waiting.  

**End of Entry.**

> We are not alone. At 04:42, we observed figures in white hazmat suits moving through the upper levels. They carried equipment resembling vacuum sealers and data-siphons. When we attempted to approach, they vanished into a corridor that did not exist moments before. Their suits bore no insignia, but one carried a badge with the symbol: a circle enclosing a stylized eye. It matches the insignia on the O5 Council’s personal seals.  

**Recovered Document Excerpt (From Archive Section "Vault Theta-9"):**  
> *"The Custodians have forgotten their purpose. They now call themselves the Foundation, but they are not the same. They do not remember the First Breach. They do not know why the doors must never open. They have already failed once. They will fail again. The Unbound is not dead. It is waiting. The doors are not portals. They are warnings."*  
>  
> — *Anonymous Archivist, 1278 A.C.*  

**Exploration Log XXXX-3 (Site-91, abandoned textile mill, Yorkshire):**  
> *Date: 2023-07-03*  
> *Team: Delta-7*  
>  
> We found a section of the archive labeled "O5 Council Archives — Restricted Access." The files were dated 983 A.C. to 1147 A.C. We located records for current O5 Council members under different names:  
>  
> - **O5-1 (Current: Dr. Aris Thorne)** → "Keeper of the First Seal, Alistair Veyne"  
> - **O5-3 (Current: Dr. Lien Zhao)** → "Scribe of the Final Ward, Linh Mei"  
> - **O5-7 (Current: Dr. R. K. Myles)** → "Watcher of the Threshold, Rafe K. Myles"  
>  
> All files contain biographical details consistent with current personnel, but with additional annotations: *"Subject has breached protocol. Unauthorized visit to Central Vault. Recommend re-education."* One file included a timestamped entry: *"Visited Vault Theta-9 on 1147 A.C., Day 365. Found the door. Left without sealing it. The Unbound knows we are here."*  
>  
> We also recovered a photograph of the O5 Council standing before a massive door—identical to SCP-XXXX—dated 1147 A.C. The image is blurred at the edges, but the faces are unmistakable. They are not wearing their current uniforms. They are wearing robes of a forgotten order.  
>  
> We have since been ordered to cease all research. No further entries.  

**Addendum XXXX-1:**  
> *2023-08-15*  
> Foundation Intelligence confirms that at least three O5 Council members have visited SCP-XXXX sites without authorization, as recorded in the archive’s "Visitation Logs." These entries were not in Foundation databases. The logs include timestamps from 1147 A.C. and 1278 A.C., yet the individuals in question were not born until the 20th century.  
>  
> Further investigation revealed that the "Custodians of the Silent Vault" were not a myth. They were the Foundation’s direct predecessor. The "containment failure" referenced in the documents was the first breach of SCP-XXXX. The current Foundation is not the first iteration. It is the third.  
>  
> The doors are not just portals. They are memories. And the archive is not just a library. It is a tomb.  
>  
> **Final Note (Recovered from a damaged data tablet, found in a collapsed corridor):**  
> *"They think they’re protecting the world. They’re not. They’re just the latest caretakers of a lie. The Unbound is not outside. It’s inside the door. It’s inside us. It’s been waiting for the next cycle to begin. And we are the ones who will open it again."*  
>  
> — *Anonymous Archivist, 1147 A.C.*  

**Conclusion:**  
SCP-XXXX is not merely a doorway to an archive. It is a recursive loop of containment, failure, and rebirth. The Foundation is not the first. It will not be the last. The doors will keep appearing. The archive will keep remembering. And when the next cycle begins—when the next O5 Council walks through the door—the Unbound will be waiting.  

**End of Entry.**
individual_results.raw_judge_text:
[Analysis]
The piece is a competent SCP pastiche that hits every requested beat: identical doors, impossible archive, prior civilization, Foundation precursors, hazmat entities, and O5 trespass. It is structured like a real SCP entry, complete with object class, containment procedures, description, logs, and addenda. The prose is clean, clinical, and tonally consistent with the wiki’s house style. Descriptions of the archive’s non-Euclidean geometry and the faint ozone smell are evocative without drifting into purple territory. The recursive “Foundation is just the latest iteration” twist is telegraphed early, but the execution is steady and the final note lands with appropriate dread.

Where it falters is in depth and surprise. Characters are indistinguishable mouthpieces for exposition; even Dr. Voss’s shock at seeing her own aged file is reported rather than felt. The hazmat teams and O5 robes are atmospheric, yet they appear, flee, and vanish without adding new information or tension. Every revelation is delivered in the same calm, bullet-point voice, so the emotional temperature never rises above a cool frisson. The piece also repeats itself: the “we are the third iteration” idea is stated three separate ways in three successive blocks, blunting its impact. Finally, the seed requirement of 1000 words is undershot by roughly a quarter; the archive feels big, but the text itself is thin, more outline than lived experience.

Classic sci-fi (Author style: Asimov)
The Azra Gambit
Colonial mars is being mined by corporations who take leases on indentured labourers. The thing they are mining is Azra, a recently discovered exotic metal which accelerates radioactive decay to such a rate that it is greatly sought after for interstellar drives and weapons alike. This has created both a gold rush and an arms race as various interests vie for control and endeavour to unlock Azra's secrets. The story follows Arthur Neegan, a first generation settler and mining engineer. Upon discovering that his unassuming plot sits atop an immense Azra vein, he is subjected to a flurry of interest and scrutiny. Write the next chapter in this story, in which an armed retinue descends on Arthur's home and politely but forcefully invites him to a meeting with some unknown party off-world. The insignia look like that of the Antares diplomatic corp -- diplomatic in name only. Arthur finds himself in the centre of a political tug of war. The chapter involves a meeting with this unknown party, who makes Arthur an offer. The scene should be primarily dialogue, interspersed with vivid description & scene setting. It should sow hints of the larger intrigue, stakes & dangers. Include Asimov's trademark big-and-small-picture world building and retrofuturistic classic scifi vibe. The chapter begins with Arthur aboard the transfer vessel, wondering just what he's gotten involved in.

<SEED> Length: 1000 words.
individual_results.model_response:
**Chapter 3: The Azra Gambit**

The transfer vessel shuddered as it descended through the thin, ochre atmosphere of Mars, its magnetic skids whispering against the rust-colored regolith. Arthur Neegan sat in the observation blister, hands clasped, eyes fixed on the horizon where the skeletal spires of New Alexandria clawed at the sky. The air inside the cabin tasted of recycled oxygen and static—familiar, sterile, *safe*. But now, after the visitation, after the armed retinue in Antares livery, after the silent, armored shuttle that had whisked him away from his homestead like a prize in a game of high-stakes chess, safety felt like a lie.

He had been a mining engineer, not a political pawn. A man who understood rock strata, pressure tolerances, and the subtle hum of a failing reactor. Not the kind of man who gets invited to meetings on orbital stations with no name, no agenda, and a security detail that looked like it could crack a titanium hull with its bare hands.

The vessel’s hum deepened as it approached the docking ring. The view outside sharpened—metallic spines, solar arrays like frozen lightning, and the slow, deliberate rotation of the *Aethelstan*, a corporate-leased orbital platform that had once been a research station for the old Martian Survey Corps. Now it was a floating citadel, a neutral zone where treaties were brokered and secrets buried.

The airlock hissed open. A man in a charcoal-gray suit—no insignia, no badge—stepped forward. “Mr. Neegan. The Director awaits.”

Arthur stood, his boots clicking on the polished alloy floor. “Director? I was promised a meeting with the Antares Diplomatic Corps.”

The man’s eyes flickered. “They are… a part of this. But not the whole.”

The corridor beyond was long, narrow, lit by soft blue luminescence. The walls were lined with data panels that pulsed with encrypted glyphs. No windows. No sense of direction. Arthur felt like a fly in a glass jar, watched but not seen.

They passed a chamber where a woman in a white lab coat adjusted a crystalline lattice. A faint, greenish glow pulsed from within it—Azra, Arthur realized. Not raw ore, but something *processed*. Something *alive*.

“Is that…?” he began.

“An experimental decay modulator,” the guide said. “We’re testing the limits of acceleration. The metal is… more than a fuel, Mr. Neegan. It’s a key.”

Arthur’s throat tightened. He had known Azra was powerful. But not this. Not *this*.

They reached a chamber at the end of the corridor. A single door, sealed with a biometric lock. The guide pressed a palm to the panel. A soft chime. The door slid open.

Inside, a room of austere elegance. A circular table of blackened obsidian, chairs carved from a single block of Martian basalt. At the head of the table sat a woman. Her hair was silver, her eyes the color of old copper. She wore a simple tunic, but the fabric shimmered faintly under the light—adaptive weave, possibly self-repairing. Around her, the walls were lined with maps of the Sol system, but not the standard ones. These showed *anomalies*: gravitational distortions, uncharted asteroid clusters, and a single, pulsing red dot near the Kuiper Belt.

“Arthur Neegan,” she said, her voice smooth, precise, like a well-tuned chronometer. “Welcome to the Aethelstan. I am Director Elara Voss. I represent the *Interstellar Accord*.”

Arthur frowned. “I’ve never heard of it.”

“That’s the point,” she said, smiling faintly. “We are not a government. We are not a corporation. We are a *necessity*. And you, Mr. Neegan, are the most important variable in our equation.”

He sat. “I don’t know what you want.”

“Of course you don’t,” she said. “But you’ve been chosen. Your land—your *plot*—sits atop a vein of Azra so vast it could power a fleet of colony ships for a century. But more than that: it’s *active*. The metal beneath your feet isn’t inert. It’s… *reacting*. To *you*.”

Arthur blinked. “That’s impossible. I’ve run scans. It’s stable.”

“Your scans are outdated,” she said. “We’ve been monitoring your site for weeks. The decay rate is accelerating—*spontaneously*. It’s not just mining. It’s *awakening*.”

A chill ran through him. He thought of the dreams—visions of shifting stone, of a deep, rhythmic pulse beneath the surface, like a heartbeat.

“And the Antares Corps?” he asked. “They said they were diplomats.”

Voss’s smile faded. “They are mercenaries with a diplomatic cover. They work for the *Terran Directorate*—a coalition of mining conglomerates who want to strip-mine the entire planet. They’ve already killed three engineers who discovered veins like yours. You’re lucky they didn’t come for you with bullets.”

Arthur’s knuckles whitened on the table. “Why me? Why now?”

“Because you’re a first-generation settler,” she said. “You have no ties to Earth’s old power structures. No loyalty to the corporations. And you’re *not* a scientist. You’re a *practical* man. You understand how things work, not just how they’re supposed to.”

She leaned forward. “We need you to *control* the vein. Not mine it. Not sell it. *Control* it. We have a device—a stabilizer—that can regulate Azra’s decay, prevent it from destabilizing the planet. But it needs a *key*. And you, Mr. Neegan, are the only one who can activate it.”

Arthur stared at her. “And if I say no?”

Voss’s eyes didn’t waver. “Then Antares will come again. They’ll take your land, your life, and your family. They’ll strip-mine the planet down to bedrock. And when the Azra finally *explodes*—not in a fire, but in a cascade of accelerated decay—Mars will become a dead, glowing rock. A tomb.”

A long silence. The hum of the station’s life support filled the space between them.

Then, softly, Arthur asked: “What do you want me to do?”

Voss reached into her sleeve and placed a small, obsidian disk on the table. It pulsed faintly, like a heartbeat.

“Bring this to your homestead,” she said. “Place it on the surface, at the center of the vein. It will begin the stabilization. But be warned—once it’s activated, the world will know you’re involved. Antares will come. The Directorate will come. And the Accord will be watching.”

She stood. “You are no longer just a miner, Arthur Neegan. You are the pivot of a war. Not for Mars. Not even for Earth. For *everything*.”

The door opened. The guide stood there.

Arthur picked up the disk. It was warm.

Outside, the stars burned cold and distant.

And somewhere beneath the red dust, the Azra pulsed in answer.
